This part is absent from the album version, where instead there’s what followed the performance of “Get Back” in the rooftop concert: Paul replies to Ringo’s wife cheering (“Thanks, Mo”) and John says something that fits the last song of  effectively the band’s last album:

“I’d like to say thank you on behalf of the group and ourselves and I hope we’ve passed the audition.”
Jojo left his home in Tucson, Arizona
Before she met Paul, Linda McCartney studied at the University of Arizona in Tucson in 1965. The two later owned a ranch there.
Jojo was a man who thought he was a loner

McCartney has never directly revealed who his inspiration for “Jojo” was. If this song was about John Lennon and Yoko Ono (which Paul denies), Jojo could be a nickname for John. However, the name “Jojo” could have also come from Jo Jo Laine, the wife of singer Denny Laine from the Moody Blues – later a member of Wings with McCartney.

One very likely solution to the mystery comes from this article, which suggests that Jojo in the song was actually a reference to Joseph Melville See Jr, Linda’s ex-husband. Paul and Linda were close to Joseph. Linda met Joseph in Tuscon, Arizona at the University of Arizona.



This song may have been the inspiration for the title to the series Jojo’s Bizarre Adventures. In the series, all the main protagonist begin as loners, but they gain friends as the story unfolds. In the ending of part 3, the character Joseph Joestar can be seen listening to this song on his Walkman.

Many believe that the song was written “under the influence” of a rock'n'roll classic written and sung 10 years earlier by the great Chuck Berry – Little Queenie.

Judge for yourselves –

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=od8nCgpumso
Also known as Urochloa mutica. Could possibly be referencing to marijuana.

Sweet Loretta Martin thought she was a woman
 But she was another man

John Lennon’s famous ad lib before the song was played on the Saville Row rooftop; ‘Sweet Loretta Fart, she though she was a cleaner, but she was a frying pan’, further emphasizes how much this song is just a series of non-sequiturs with an inventive blues backdrop.

Get back, get back
 Get back to where you once belonged
 Get back, get back
 Get back to where you once belonged

“Get back to where you once belonged” is McCartney’s reworking of the line, “Get back to where you should be,” which came from a song Harrison wrote called “Sour Milk Sea,” and was eventually recorded by Jackie Lomax in 1968, with three of the bands members lending their talents on the single.

When this song was released, there was a high controversy because the public perceived it almost as a anti-immigration song. Paul later revealed that the song had been inspired by Enoch Powell’s infamous “rivers of blood” speech, but he insisted he was not against foreigners. It was simply a point of view he saw and went along with.

John Lennon would later claim that this lyric was aimed at Yoko Ono, and — according to Lennon —McCartney would often make sideways glances in her direction when singing this in the studio.
